sect1.title: Getting Started With MacPorts
sect1.para: This document will provide a short guide to the basics of a MacPorts Portfile. A Portfile is actually a Tcl script run by the port system. Despite this, the Portfile syntax is very straightforward.
In order to work with MacPorts, you will need to download and install it on your system. The Obtaining and Installing MacPorts sections of this guide describes the process in detail.

In order for these commands to work, you're going to need permission to write to certain areas of your MacPorts tree. You need to be able to write to ${prefix}/var/macports/build and ${prefix}/var/macports/distfiles. You could run all of these commands as a superuser (prefix the commands with sudo), but you might accidentally install a broken package that way, or otherwise damage up your MacPorts installation. Another option is to change the owner of just those directories to your user, so you can write to those directories but not your whole ${prefix} tree. To do this, run chown username ${prefix}/var/macports/build and chown -R username ${prefix}/var/macports/distfiles.
Since you're interested in writing a Portfile, you should invoke the port with the -d (debugging option) switch. This will display useful messages that are usually suppressed while running MacPorts.

sect2.title: Fetching the Sources
sect2.para: The first step is to choose a piece of software to port. For this example, we'll be porting ircII, a popular Internet relay chat client.
We can start with a simple Portfile describing the basic attributes of ircII, such as its name, version, and the site where we can download the sources.
Create a working directory named ircII and inside it create a file named Portfile with the following contents:

example.title: ircII Portfile
example.programlisting: # $Id: $ PortSystem 1.0 name ircii version 20020912 categories irc maintainers kevin@opendarwin.org description an IRC and ICB client long_description The ircII program is a full screen, termcap based \ interface to Internet Relay Chat. It gives full access \ to all of the normal IRC functions, plus a variety of \ additional options. homepage http://www.eterna.com.au/ircii/ master_sites ftp://ircftp.au.eterna.com.au/pub/ircII/

sect2.para: A Portfile consists of key/value pairs. This example uses the following keys:

listitem.para: Every Portfile starts with #$Id: $. This is a RCS Id tag (commented out with the '#' character so that MacPorts is not confused by the tag).
Following the RCS Id tag comes the PortSystem version declaration. Currently the only valid version declaration is PortSystem 1.0.
The name and version keys describe the name and version of the software.

The categories key is a list of the logical categories to which the software belongs; this is used for organizational purposes. The first entry in categories should match the directory in which the port's directory resides in the ports tree.
The maintainers key should contain the email address of the person or persons maintaining the port.
description provides a short (one line) description of the port, while long_description holds a more detailed description of the software.
To refer to the main web site of the software, the homepage key is used.
The master_sites key should contain a list of sites where the distribution sources may be downloaded by the port system.

sect2.para: MacPorts uses the terms 'keys' and 'options' interchangeably since most keys are used as options of a particular task in the porting process.
At this point, the Portfile is complete enough to download ircII. By default, MacPorts will append the version to name and assume sources are in a gzipped tar archive with the .tar.gz suffix.

sect2.title: Verifying the Downloaded File
sect2.para: Notice that MacPorts first checks for a local copy of ircii-20020912.tar.gz and doesn't find it, so it then downloads from the remove site. sect2.title: Running a configure Script
sect2.para: Now that the sources have been extracted into a work directory in the Portfile directory, we can configure the sources to compile with the desired options. By default MacPorts assumes the software you're porting uses an autoconf configure script and will pass the --prefix=${prefix} argument to configure, specifying that the software should be installed in the directory tree used by MacPorts.

ircII's standard set of options is fine for a base install on Darwin, so we won't add anything to the configure phase and instead just move on to the build phase. Please look at the later chapters in this Guide for more information about the Configuration phase.

sect2.title: Installing the Finished Product on the System
sect2.para: The former method of including a contents list has been made obsolete by the destroot mechanism. With destroot the software is installed into a directory tree below in the work directory. While some software (like ircII) does not require any special tweaks to be installed into the destroot, others (like ncftp) need the install.destroot option in order to correctly install into the destroot.
Take a look at some of our ports to see more examples on how to use the destroot.destdir option.
Now we have a complete Portfile. Run the installation step to add your port to your own registry.

sect2.title: Additional Options
sect2.para: There are additional options that are commonly used in Portfiles. The following are commonly used options that may be useful:

listitem.para: distfile is the name and version combined with the extract.suffix (by default ${name}-${version}.tar.gz) by default, and is used by MacPorts to fetch the distribution file. If the name of the file on the server is not the same as ${name}-${version}.tar.gz you can use this option to override the default distfile name.

depends_lib is used if the port needs other libraries or binaries to be installed in order to configure and run. It takes three terms, separated by colons. The first term is bin or lib. This defines the search path the port system will look for the dependency in. If bin is specified, $PATH is searched for the dependency. If lib is specified, the library path is searched instead. The second term is a regular expression that is used to search the search path for the dependency. Usually the name of the library is good enough. The port system will append .dylib to the reg-ex so only dynamic libraries will be matched. The third term is the name of the port that can provide the dependency if it is not satisfied by something already installed on the system.

patchfiles is a list of patches to be applied to the port (needed for the software to compile/run or install correctly). Patches are usually provided in a files/ directory in the same directory as the Portfile.

sect2.para: Please take a look at the other chapters in this Guide for more detailed information about these and other options.

sect2.title: Don't quote or wrap items in '{}'.
sect2.para: Frequently people submit ports with the description or configure arguments quoted, or wrapped in curly brackets. In general this is not correct.

sect2.title: Debugging and Verbose Messages
sect2.para: You should use the -d and -v switches to port to enable debugging and verbose messages, respectively.

sect2.title: Use a Local Portfile Repository
sect2.para: Enable a second local source (Portfile) repository for your uncommitted ports. Edit your sources.conf file and add:file:///User/foo/mports-dev (or wherever your local mport tree is). Place all your Portfiles inside their corresponding portdirs (reflecting the name of the port), which should in turn be placed inside directories that reflect their primary category (the first one listed for their categories entry).
Create an index file from the local source repository root. This will also perform a simple syntax check on the Portfiles contained therein.

sect2.title: Testing Destroot
sect2.para: First run port install without root privileges, this is a good way to check that the port installs into the destroot and not directly into the main prefix directory, or elsewhere in the system. This should succeed up to the point macports attempts to copy the port from the destroot into the macports prefix. Once you are confident the port is correctly destrooted install the port into the macports prefix using root privileges.

Ensure the Port installs into the destroot and does not install anything onto the system directly, most software that uses autoconf should behave correctly automatically as macports sets DESTDIR by default. If files are directly installed to the system they will not be registered and packaging will fail.

sect2.para: Uninstall the port

sect2.title: Try the Port on a Clean Machine
sect2.para:
Make sure the port builds, installs and uninstalls on a "clean machine". A clean machine should have a clean install of the OS, to avoid missing dependencies. Using a chrooted version of the OS to install and test ports makes this much easier, see the chroot
HOWTO for more details on how to set up the chroot.

sect2.title: Clean the Working Directory after an Error
sect2.para: Clean the working source directory for a port. This will allow a clean reinstall if an error was encountered earlier in the build process.

sect1.title: Where can I ask for advice?
sect1.para: Either on the macports-dev@lists.macosforge.org mailing list, or on the #macports channel on irc.freenode.net. Don't be afraid to ask questions! You should also look at the later sections of the guideand the portfile(7) and portstyle(7) manpages for more information.

sect1.title: How do I submit my Ports
sect1.para: See the submission chapter for all the information on how to submit a port properly.

sect1.title: More Example Portfiles

example.title: Expat Portfile
example.programlisting:
# $Id: Portfile,v 1.14 2003/07/30 14:35:39 fkr Exp $
PortSystem 1.0
name libxslt version 1.0.21 homepage http://www.xmlsoft.org/ description gnome xslt library and xsltproc categories textproc platforms darwin maintainers mike+libxslt@gene-hacker.net master_sites ftp://xmlsoft.org/ \ ftp://ftp.gnome.org/pub/GNOME/sources/libxslt/1.0/
checksums md5 9cc0491e2584788748eb7069ea1d5277 depends_lib lib:libxml2:libxml2 patchfiles patch-aclocal.m4 patch-configure patch-ltmain.sh
long_description Gnome library for applying XSL stylesheet transformations to \ xml files, comes with several useful binaries.

example.title: Neon Portfile
example.programlisting:
# $Id: Portfile,v 1.14 2003/07/30 14:35:39 fkr Exp $
PortSystem 1.0 name neon version 0.23.4
categories www maintainers rooneg@electricjellyfish.net description An HTTP and WebDAV client library with a C interface
master_sites http://www.webdav.org/neon/ checksums md5 56b380a7352c68d425b1d3d3d610f994
depends_lib lib:libexpat.0.4:expat configure.env LDFLAGS='-L"${prefix}/lib"' CPPFLAGS='-I"${prefix}/include"'
configure.args --with-ssl \ --with-force-ssl \ --enable-xml \ --enable-shared \ --with-expat

sect1.para: For more examples, you can browse the directory tree of MacPorts' mports directory and have a look at the Portfiles of your favorite ports.
For more information about some options used in these Portfile examples that were not covered in this chapter, please take a look at the following chapters of this Guide.
